meaning: become less in amount or intensity
example: Yes, Joseph Addison, I hear and I will obey within Reason, for it appears that the Curiosity you speak of has in no Way abated.

meaning: markedly different from an accepted norm
example: On a world level, the eruption at the Norte Chico was improbable, even aberrant.

meaning: temporary cessation or suspension
example: And off he’d go to his chessboard, without his mother’s permission, leaving his school assignments in abeyance.

meaning: run away, often taking something or somebody along
example: Cora spoke of her mother, Mabel, who absconded one day and left her to the inconstant mercy of the world.

meaning: marked by temperance in indulgence
example: “I should have guessed. Too opulent for your abstemious revolutionary and yourself, I take it?”

meaning: scold or reprimand; take to task
example: The rock might be angry about something that people did and rejoice over some other action, the rock might admonish people or ask for favours.

meaning: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
example: Cato and Pliny had said that a bottle made of ivy could be used to establish whether wine had been adulterated with water, as the wine would be expelled, leaving the water behind.

meaning: characterized by an appreciation of beauty or good taste
example: By definition, aesthetic is “that which concerns the beautiful.”

meaning: a sum total of many heterogeneous things taken together
example: The index of aggregate weekly payrolls, which tallies the combined weekly wages of all U.S. workers, rose 0.3% from May.

meaning: liveliness and eagerness
example: “Certainly,” he replied with alacrity, and stood up to put it in train for speaking.

meaning: provide physical relief, as from pain
example: As a scientist, she believed that it was her obligation to perform medical research that would help alleviate human suffering.

meaning: bring or combine together or with something else
example: The mistress used to be kept in a minor house or apartment of her own, and now they’ve amalgamated things.

meaning: having more than one possible meaning
example: But the diagnosis baffles many clinicians, who call it ambiguous, vague and unwieldy.

meaning: mixed feelings or emotions
example: One odd ambivalence was how some letters, otherwise all but championing Mr. Muhammad, would recoil at the expression “white devils.”

meaning: make better
example: She had a notion about the air down here and its ameliorating effects on the circulation.

meaning: locating something at a time when it couldn't have existed
example: “I love finding anachronisms in movies and shows.”

meaning: similar or equivalent in some respects
example: It may be analogous, in some respects, to the panic once experienced by poor and working-class whites faced with desegregation—the fear of a sudden demotion in the nation’s racial hierarchy.

meaning: a state of lawlessness and disorder
example: Paula had the air of a real ideologue; she could, Ifemelu imagined, slip easily into anarchy, stand at the forefront of protests, defying the clubs of policemen and the taunts of unbelievers.

meaning: deviating from the general or common order or type
example: This alone makes it extremely anomalous; it means that our planetary system consists of four rocky inner planets, four gassy outer giants, and a tiny, solitary iceball.

meaning: a feeling of intense dislike
example: John had not much affection for his mother and sisters, and an antipathy to me.

meaning: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
example: And she never lets our apathy discourage her.

meaning: make peace with
example: The first resolution was designed to appease the Deep South by confirming that the Constitution prohibited any federal legislation limiting or ending the slave trade until 1808.

meaning: inform somebody of something
example: Sotheby’s apprised Mr. Big of the fact that his “Rembrandt” was appraised as worthless. as if/as though.

meaning: official acceptance or agreement
example: Other scientists bent down and with equal approbation scooped up handfuls of dirt.

meaning: suitable for a particular person, place, or situation
example: He appropriated both, after a moment of sniffing the muzzle of the pistol.

meaning: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion
example: The climb up to the arches and stained-glass windows was long and arduous.

meaning: simple and natural; without cunning or deceit
example: “You want something?” said Gloria, eyes wide in an apparently artless complexity that fooled her huge “nursemaid” not at all.

meaning: someone who practices self denial as a spiritual discipline
example: He remembered how once, as a youth, he had compelled his father to let him go and join the ascetics, how he had taken leave of him, how he had gone and never returned.

meaning: marked by care and persistent effort
example: He had learned these three arts and nothing else during the diligent, assiduous years of his youth.

meaning: provide physical relief, as from pain
example: This is the kind of thing we do, to assuage pain.

meaning: become weaker, in strength, value, or magnitude
example: In Pascal’s account of why the mercury does not descend in the Torricellian tube the formal and material causes are so attenuated as to be uninteresting, and the final cause has disappeared completely.

meaning: disposed to venture or take risks
example: Foreigners weren’t always so considerate, though, and he usually lashed out at anyone audacious enough to address him.

meaning: of a stern or strict bearing or demeanor
example: And they took an austere view of the visual.

meaning: declare or affirm solemnly and formally as true
example: I averred that I was honored by his recollection, no less than by his attendance upon the first performance.

meaning: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
example: But this banality of violence can never excuse America, because America makes no claim to the banal.

meaning: be in contradiction with
example: I make myself as small as possible, as if my size could belie our closeness.

meaning: doing or producing good
example: She forgot the names of the servants and even of her own children, yet she always managed to be present, like a cheerful, beneficent spirit, at whose slightest footfall clocks began to wind themselves.

meaning: support and strengthen
example: Khrushchev viewed a new alliance with Cuba as a chance to extend Soviet influence to America's backyard; Fidel Castro welcomed the chance to bolster his defenses against his aggressive American neighbor.

meaning: ostentatiously lofty in style
example: “And there is a certain bombast in the way we speak that I had also forgotten. I started feeling truly at home again when I started being bombastic!”

meaning: ill-mannered and coarse in behavior or appearance
example: “To begin with, I could teach these boorish ogres how to eat properly.”

meaning: grow and flourish
example: She could feel it burgeoning within her, welling up like tears.

meaning: polish and make shiny
example: The top part of the painting, where the sky would have been, was covered in burnished silver.

meaning: a support usually of stone or brick
example: As in the mica mine in North Carolina, long wooden planks and struts buttressed the walls and ceiling.

meaning: having an unpleasant sound
example: The politics of the 1790s was a truly cacophonous affair.

meaning: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
example: Darwin had called these variants “sports,” implying a streak of capricious whimsy in the natural world.

meaning: verbal punishment
example: The one discordant note was also the note people are still talking about: Robert De Niro’s expletive-dotted castigation of President Trump, delivered before introducing Bruce Springsteen’s performance.

meaning: substance that initiates or accelerates a chemical reaction
example: It sounds unbelievable to me that one person can be a catalyst for such a change.

meaning: capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action
example: Mr. Justice Wargrave, mellowed by the excellent port, was being amusing in a caustic fashion, Dr. Armstrong and Tony Marston were listening to him.

meaning: the use of tricks to deceive someone
example: In their zeal to avoid resurrecting the sport’s reputation for chicanery, they tried to bury the incident.

meaning: change from a liquid to a thickened or solid state
example: A surgeon will probe the exposed brain before slicing into it with a scalpel, using the path of coagulated blood to trace the path of the ball.

meaning: the closing section of a musical composition
example: The concert opener, Haydn’s Variations in F minor, was limpid and gorgeously colored, with playful flourishes that led to an explosive ________.

meaning: powerfully persuasive
example: Studies have been done, in fact, in which experts in a given field have analyzed such random phenomena and come up with cogent “explanations” for the patterns.

meaning: corresponding in size or degree or extent
example: In interviews here, my previous findings were confirmed: with the exception of those trained in professions where they can set up independent practice, they can find jobs commensurate with their education only outside the South.

meaning: a publication containing a variety of works
example: The English Dancing Master, John Playford’s compendium of catchy regional folk songs and dances, was the most successful musical publication of Oliver Cromwell’s Commonwealth.

meaning: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
example: Onstage, there was absolutely nothing complaisant about her.

meaning: disposed to act in accordance with someone's wishes
example: It's a stretch, but I'm thinking that maybe I can lace one of the sheriff’s cigarettes with the drug, make him compliant, and then just finish the job.

meaning: making or willing to make concessions
example: I did, I suppose, hope that she might finally relent a little and make some conciliatory response or other, allowing us once and for all to put the whole episode behind us.

meaning: excuse, overlook, or make allowances for
example: My brother had privately agonized over whether to go or not—titillated by the opportunity but knowing it was sneaky and dishonorable, the sort of behavior my parents would never condone.

meaning: be confusing or perplexing to
example: For as long as I could remember, people had always confounded me.

meaning: an expert able to appreciate a field
example: Mommy was a connoisseur of ministers; she knew them the way a French wine connoisseur knows Beaujolais red from Vouvray white.

meaning: the act of competing as for profit or a prize
example: For fifteen minutes, they were left alone with the cameras rolling, with instructions to discuss any topic from their marriage that had become a point of contention.

meaning: showing an inclination to disagree
example: Klingons could be notoriously contentious when it came to their food.

meaning: feeling or expressing pain or sorrow
example: At the hurt in his blue eyes she was instantly contrite.

meaning: a difficult problem
example: “No, no,” said Emma, “it will not reckon low. A conundrum of Mr. Weston’s shall clear him and his next neighbour. Come, sir, pray let me hear it.”

meaning: be adjacent or come together
example: Brawls erupted when rival gangs converged on the same pauper’s field.

meaning: highly complex or intricate
example: The tickets he wrote out were long and convoluted and very elaborate.

meaning: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful
example: He shuddered at his own craven circumlocution, using so meaningless a word to obscure so hideous a truth.

meaning: cause to lose courage
example: Many had been separated from loved ones during the fire and now had the daunting task of searching through a ruined city for them.

meaning: propriety in manners and conduct
example: So decorum is, literally, speaking your audience’s language.

meaning: an option that is selected automatically
example: I mean, not just by default because I am in love with Dee, but I feel like these people are my people or something.

meaning: courteous regard for people's feelings
example: I’m not sure what kind of deference, if any, is due here: Is she my supervisor now?

meaning: represented accurately or precisely
example: But the rare urge west had fixed upon our family, and so my aunt crossed boundaries not delineated in space.

meaning: attack the good name and reputation of someone
example: I know my parents had their reasons to raise us without religion, but it still upsets me to hear my grandmother's peaceful beliefs denigrated.

meaning: treat or speak of with contempt
example: Everything was custom engineered—“no hand-me-down magnets, no industrial discards . . . ‘no patch work,’ ” as the Joliots’ emissary Maurice Nahmias had derided the old standards.

meaning: a compound obtained from another compound
example: The same thing goes for taking the derivative.

meaning: lacking vitality or spirit; lifeless
example: In the wake of the reapers’ scythes the black land showed again through the stubble, no longer moist and rich but bone-hard, desiccated, and beginning to crack in all directions under the burning sun.

meaning: marked by lack of definite plan, purpose, or enthusiasm
example: They sat and praised Tanzania and dreamed about stockfish and were still talking desultorily when a Peugeot 403 sped across the street.

meaning: something immaterial that interferes with action or progress
example: Information is a beacon, a cudgel, an olive branch, a deterrent— all depending on who wields it and how.

meaning: thunderous verbal attack
example: Jacobs attended city council meetings, but only sporadically, which was a good thing, in C.P.’s view, since Jacobs’ diatribes left listeners with the impression that the man was unhinged.

meaning: a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses
example: The same moralistic dichotomy that Jefferson saw inside the United States between discernible heroes and villains, he also projected into the international arena.

meaning: lack of self-assurance
example: Invariably, it took Ben and Mary Anne months before they could overcome their native diffidence, which actually was an obstinate refusal to make themselves vulnerable.

meaning: spread out; not concentrated in one place
example: All were the same, a brilliant white diffused with gray, I closed my eyes for a moment and looked again and still no change.

meaning: a message that departs from the main subject
example: After a page-long digression on pacifism, Christianity, and the Roman Empire, Keegan returns to what is wrong with Clausewitz’s dictum and with the modern understanding of war it captures.

meaning: a song or hymn of mourning as a memorial to a dead person
example: The story droned on, speeded up for the attack, grew sad over the wounds, struck a dirge at the burials on the great plains.

meaning: free somebody from an erroneous belief
example: He never claimed to be that which he was not, but did not disabuse people of their assumptions.

meaning: having or revealing keen insight and good judgment
example: “I am quite good at discerning lies. I hear none from you. Your story also fits with what Hazel Levesque told us.”

meaning: not in agreement or harmony
example: The “Danse Macabre” came to a tempestuous and discordant end.

meaning: the state of being held in low esteem
example: Of particular interest were details that could be used to humiliate and discredit Ellsberg—tales of recreational drug use, and rumors that Daniel and Patricia enjoyed visiting nudist camps.

meaning: a difference between conflicting facts or claims or opinions
example: He said he did not believe there were such large ________ between what local drivers earned compared with their peers in surrounding states.

meaning: constituting a separate entity or part
example: By 1910, the greatest minds in biology had accepted that discrete particles of information carried on chromosomes were the carriers of hereditary information.

meaning: not straightforward or candid
example: But any suggestion that litigants need not worry about policy reform because they can always sue for damages would be disingenuous—particularly as applied to race discrimination cases.

meaning: unaffected by concern for one's own welfare
example: In word and act impeccable, disinterested toward all the realm—though it is king’s justice to hold one man abhorred and love another; no man alive could say Odysseus wronged him.

meaning: taken apart at the points of connection
example: Both my voice and body have a jerky, disjointed quality, like a puppet being manipulated by unseen forces.

meaning: stop associating with
example: He dismisses the corporal with a slight wag of his chin.

meaning: express a negative opinion of
example: Jordan has tough laws that forbid slandering the royal family or writing articles that ________ the armed forces and security services.

meaning: fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind
example: The important thing was that Barack had managed to process his life story, snapping together the disparate pieces of his Afro-Kansan-Indonesian-Hawaiian-Chicagoan identity, writing himself into a sort of wholeness this way.

meaning: behave unnaturally or affectedly
example: To dissemble your feelings, to control your face, to do what everyone else was doing, was an instinctive reaction.

meaning: cause to become widely known
example: The legend that the herbicides are toxic only to plants and so pose no threat to animal life has been widely disseminated, but unfortunately it is not true.

meaning: separation into component parts
example: If the price of peace was the dissolution of the Union, many people felt that compensation lay in stopping human slaughter.

meaning: disagreeable sounds
example: In some modern music, many of these dissonances are heard as pleasant or interesting or jazzy and don't need to be resolved.

meaning: cause to expand as if by internal pressure
example: It is misleading to describe the expansion of the universe as a sort of distending bubble viewed from the outside.

meaning: undergo condensation
example: The General Assembly had made it illegal to distill whiskey because it was made from grain, and grain was needed for food.

meaning: move or draw apart
example: One end of the thing was pressed into the bank, but along its length it diverged, sticking out slightly into the stream.

meaning: take away possessions from someone
example: Robert Oppenheimer could no more divest himself of political concerns than he could give up music and wine; they were all essential to his method of engaging with the outside world.

meaning: a representation of a person's thinking with symbolic marks
example: Open to the public, the Marshall Library was also being certified for the storage of classified documents.

meaning: pertaining to a code of beliefs accepted as authoritative
example: But for all the attention paid to such rituals, Buddhism as practiced by the Sherpas was a refreshingly supple and non- dogmatic religion.

meaning: inactive but capable of becoming active
example: For the dormant mud frogs we had been for so long.

meaning: fool or hoax
example: He could not be accused of being a dupe of the government or of having gone soft.

meaning: joyously unrestrained
example: The crew’s girl magnet was Harry Brooks, a good-looking, ebullient radioman and waist gunner from Michigan.

meaning: selecting what seems best of various styles or ideas
example: You say that you hear me, that you understand, but 1 am not so sure that the force of my Mecca—The Mecca—can be translated into your new and eclectic tongue.

meaning: capacity or power to produce a desired result
example: In this domain, the prize for efficacy goes to the Cantonese dialect of Chinese, whose brevity grants residents of Hong Kong a rocketing memory span of about 10 digits.

meaning: audacious behavior that you have no right to
example: Perhaps he had found a means of assaulting the effrontery of M. Minkoff.

meaning: a mournful poem; a lament for the dead
example: Word spread quickly on the street that a small elegy of scythes had entered the Tonist cloister.

meaning: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response
example: To investigate this question Joris Lammers at Tilburg University, in the Netherlands, and Adam Galinsky at Northwestern University, in Illinois, have conducted a series of experiments which attempted to ________ states of powerfulness and powerlessness in the minds of volunteers.

meaning: make more attractive, as by adding ornament or color
example: “A terrible secret,” Bethan called it, enjoying the attention she received as she retold the embellished story.

meaning: derived from experiment and observation rather than theory
example: This aspiration towards demonstration was not confined to what we would think of as the empirical sciences but was also commonplace in theology.

meaning: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating
example: Dunstaple was a composer with a new and enchanting style that everyone wanted to emulate, and musicians fell over themselves praising the startling new sound of English triads.

meaning: native to or confined to a certain region
example: In Cordoba Province in Argentina, however, chronic arsenic poisoning, accompanied by arsenical skin cancers, is endemic because of the contamination of drinking water derived from rock formations containing arsenic.

meaning: weaken physically, mentally, or morally
example: You may attempt to defend your enervating use of the passive voice by pointing out that the only alternative is excessive reliance upon the first person personal pronoun or upon the pontifical We.

meaning: call forth
example: These were, I shortly found, connected almost solely with the dusty nature of the job, and of the consequent thirst engendered in the operators.

meaning: increase
example: Then they say stuff to me like, “That’s good, Andy, but couldn’t you have improved this part or ________ this section?”

meaning: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day
example: Compared to a star, we are like mayflies, fleeting ephemeral creatures who live out their whole lives in the course of a single day.

meaning: steadiness of mind under stress
example: Once Y-12 was operational, their equanimity made them superb operators.

meaning: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
example: She refused to equivocate on the issue of school desegregation, and in the Hispanic community she became an important, heroic voice.

meaning: having or showing profound knowledge
example: It doesn’t matter how civilized and erudite the husband is.

meaning: understandable only by an enlightened inner circle
example: The chaplain memorized the prophetic words solemnly, entranced further by their esoteric import.

meaning: a formal expression of praise for someone who has died
example: Obama is to deliver ________ in honor of those who died.

meaning: an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one
example: Even she, who knew nothing of military strategy or journalistic convention, understood a euphemism for retreat.

meaning: make worse
example: But maybe his fatigue is exacerbated by the potassium iodide he's taking.

meaning: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
example: The vibe even approached easygoing and carefree — as if Hollywood felt it had exculpated itself with all of the serious talk on the red carpet and the sharp-edged jokes Mr. Meyers cracked during his monologue.

meaning: a pressing or urgent situation
example: I visualized a self-appointed jury of twelve people who condemned him to death and were forced by exigencies of the case to be their own executioners.

meaning: an inference about the future based on known facts
example: “Ernest loved technical extrapolation, and we had fun drawing such an accelerator.”

meaning: cleverly amusing in tone
example: I don't know whether he was just trying to be facetious or if he actually worried that I walked around campus acting like a raving lunatic.

meaning: make easier
example: The indictment charged eleven of us with complicity in over two hundred acts of sabotage aimed at facilitating violent revolution and an armed invasion of the country.

meaning: containing or based on incorrect reasoning
example: As Bunny rattled on he would sit smoking with deep, resolute drags, pretending not to understand Bun’s fallacious Italian.

meaning: devoid of intelligence
example: As she walked about the yellowing hillsides or worked at easy tasks, her lips were curled in a perpetual fatuous smile.

meaning: attempting to win favor by flattery
example: Which of the following would best be considered fawning?

meaning: exhibiting an agreeably appropriate manner or style
example: Though no such felicitous circumstance transpired, still I walked with light enough step.

meaning: feelings of great warmth and intensity
example: I admitted his great revolutionary fervor, but I felt that his zeal was a trifle excessive.

meaning: a rectangular piece of cloth of distinctive design
example: The flags on the front rudders stiffened, and we could now see the eyes painted on the flags.

meaning: young bird that has just become capable of flying
example: This was the most important way he kept himself informed about the hundreds of things happening in the fledgling nation.

meaning: treat with contemptuous disregard
example: She wasn’t used to my flouting the rules.

meaning: try to stir up
example: Even as Tisquantum attempted to foment Indian distrust of Massasoit, he told the colonists that Massasoit was going to double-cross them by leading a joint attack on Plymouth with the Narragansett.

meaning: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
example: To forestall her, he said, “We’ll give you fifteen a week, starting...”

meaning: prudence in avoiding waste
example: Snap judgments can be made in a snap because they are frugal, and if we want to protect our snap judgments, we have to take steps to protect that frugality.

meaning: producing no result or effect
example: We saw quick glimpses of the enemy lines: heads and rifles now raised, watching the futile approach, waiting for a moment to fire.

meaning: take exception to
example: He spoke with an earnestness that it was hard to gainsay.

meaning: full of trivial conversation
example: His voice was nasal, garrulous, W. C. Fields with a bad case of Long Island lockjaw.

meaning: stab or urge on as if with a pointed stick
example: Alan scowls at me, not sure if I’m being sincere or goading him.

meaning: an impression in a surface, as made by a blow
example: The roof of the tunnel was scraping his shoulders and he was afraid that it would tear through the dry suit and gouge into his skin as well.

meaning: lofty in style
example: In a grandiloquent, newsreel-style voice, the show’s narrator, Westbrook Van Voorhis, began his report: “Today, at the eastern extremity of the state of Pennsylvania, a remarkable construction project is transforming the face of the countryside.”

meaning: temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
example: Even now, Izzy thought, her sister seemed less effervescent, less gregarious, as if a damper had been closed.

meaning: innocent and free of deceit
example: So Ruth rose up and out of her guileless inefficiency to claim her bit of balm right after the preparation of dinner and just before the return of her husband from his office.

meaning: naive and easily deceived or tricked
example: I can hardly believe he is so gullible that the sailors are able to fool him like this.

meaning: a loud bombastic declamation expressed with strong emotion
example: The boys were harangued by a man in a full beard.

meaning: all of the same or similar kind or nature
example: But although he speculated that the atom was mostly empty space rather than a homogenous mass speckled with charged nuggets, he had not yet conceived an alternative model.

meaning: extravagant exaggeration
example: Buster’s claim that his dog could read was hyperbole.

meaning: someone who attacks cherished ideas or institutions
example: But Wagner wasn't the only composer who was guilty of creating unnecessary clutter in the eyes of an iconoclast like Satie.

meaning: the worship of objects or images as gods
example: She must have looked into our eyes and seen the shining idolatry there and understood that she was trapped.

meaning: not subject or susceptible to change or variation
example: This phrase, ‘immutable mobiles’, sums up neatly the epistemological paradox of the fact: facts can be moved around, transferred from one person to another, without being degraded, or so at least the story goes.

meaning: make worse or less effective
example: All rulers of all ages have tried to impose a false view of the world upon their followers, but they could not afford to encourage any illusion that tended to impair military efficiency.

meaning: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
example: The three of them nodded, Blue Eyes smiling, Moby swigging from his bottle, Tool impassive.

meaning: be a hindrance or obstacle to
example: He was half tempted to go pick it for Trina, but he knew she’d scold him within an inch of his life if he dared impede the progress of the forest.

meaning: preventing especially liquids to pass or diffuse through
example: But it is illusion to think that there is anything fragile about the life of the earth; surely this is the toughest membrane imaginable in the universe, opaque to probability, impermeable to death.

meaning: marked by extreme calm and composure
example: Chamberlin had planned the meeting as a trap to try to shatter Holmes’s imperturbable façade, and was impressed with Holmes’s ability to maintain his insouciance despite the rancor in the room.

meaning: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
example: Behind it trailed a growing bunch of revelers, dancing along with the beat, drinking and throwing their empty bottles to shatter against the huge, impervious machine.

meaning: incapable of being appeased or pacified
example: She set about on a disguised but implacable vigilance.

meaning: suggested though not directly expressed
example: Most striking, perhaps, is the overwhelming evidence that implicit bias measures are disassociated from explicit bias measures.

meaning: burst inward
example: And now I’m struck with a crippling wave of panic that starts in my chest and pulls like a lethal gravity, collapsing my lungs until I’ve imploded so deep within myself, I can’t breathe.

meaning: without knowledge or intention
example: Remembering the delectable meal the fisher had inadvertently provided for him, the young dog determined to repeat it.

meaning: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
example: To Lawrence, however, the assignment seemed both inchoate and potentially overwhelming.

meaning: the quality of disagreeing
example: Buffalo Bill’s Wild West may indeed have been an “incongruity,” as the directors had declared in rejecting his request for a concession within Jackson Park, but the citizens of Chicago had fallen in love.

meaning: lacking worth or importance
example: Wondering whether I have or want one, trying to decide if the end of existence is a tragedy, a comedy, or as inconsequential as that chem lab I forgot to turn in last week.

meaning: make into a whole or make part of a whole
example: Regardless of what material you are trying to incorporate, thoroughly understanding the aesthetics and values will be highly beneficial to preserving the integrity and authenticity of both the music and culture.

meaning: not fixed or known in advance
example: If faced with the Solomonic task of sacrificing the life of one newborn for an indeterminate number of fetuses, what number might you choose?

meaning: a state of extreme poverty or destitution
example: It is a fine thing, reader, to be lifted in a moment from indigence to wealth—a very fine thing; but not a matter one can comprehend, or consequently enjoy, all at once.

meaning: disinclined to work or exertion
example: She worried that she was becoming indolent and losing her English.

meaning: unable to move or resist motion
example: Even then I kept seeing the soldier’s body tumbling toward the water, splashing down hard, how inert and heavy it was, how completely dead.

meaning: lacking in sophistication or worldliness
example: Even in the happiest times he’d made fun of my California accent, my secondhand overcoat and my room barren of tasteful bibelots, but in such an ingenuous way I couldn’t possibly do anything but laugh.

meaning: existing as an essential constituent or characteristic
example: In my humble opinion, the prescribed story structure, the limited length, and the other restrictions inherent to film cause the truth to be treated as a handicap.

meaning: not injurious to physical or mental health
example: It was innocuous: an infusion of chamomile, nothing more.

meaning: barely able to be perceived
example: She was near insensible by the time we reached it.

meaning: suggest in an indirect or covert way; give to understand
example: And he shot into the crook of one of Glerk's arms and insinuated himself into the fleshy folds of his body, and was, once again, the happiest dragon in the world.

meaning: lacking interest or significance or impact
example: It was cold outside, and dark, and a leaky, insipid mist lay swollen in the air and trickled down the large, unpolished stone blocks of the houses and the pedestals of monuments.

meaning: lack of openness to new ideas; narrow-mindedness
example: I exaggerate only slightly: British theatre was marked by its cosy insularity and its fog-isolates-Europe attitude towards the continental mainland.

meaning: difficult to manage or mold
example: Many mathematical problems are so intractable, and experiments involving them so expensive, that this kind of probabilistic simulation is the only alternative to giving up on them.

meaning: stubborn refusal to compromise or change
example: Fed up with the Housing Authority’s intransigence, leading 150 protesters, Ann took over a meeting between the city council and representatives of the DHA.

meaning: fill or cover completely, usually with water
example: Residents of Cedar Rapids are waiting anxiously as the quickly rising river threatens to ________ their city with devastating floodwaters.

meaning: made tough by habitual exposure
example: She said she was long ago inured to shocks, and insisted on having P. D. rescue me.

meaning: abusive language used to express blame or censure
example: Churchill combined their example with his father Randolph’s gift for invective.

meaning: quickly aroused to anger
example: As Reed describes it: The case before the jury involved an irascible gentleman who lived next door to a filling station.

meaning: uncertain how to act or proceed
example: My courage, watery and irresolute to begin with, ebbed away.

meaning: an established line of travel or access
example: On the recommendation of a friend, I called Abercrombie & Kent, and soon found myself ogling brochures and ________ of Nile cruises on various sizes of boats.

meaning: brief and to the point
example: She turns red and grins, and when she sits down, it’s Bobby’s turn—he moves like John Travolta in Pulp Fiction, shaking his hips with a laconic tilt, turning his feet more than his body.

meaning: a feeling of lack of interest or energy
example: A cold lassitude came over him and he passed into a dreaming, inert stupor, full of cramp and pain.

meaning: potentially existing but not presently evident or realized
example: What would a society of eunuchs achieve?—But of course they are not eunuchs, in somer, but rather more comparable to preadolescents: not castrate, but latent.

meaning: praise, glorify, or honor
example: I praised the response as “magnificent” to the press, lauding our people for “defying unprecedented intimidation by the state.”

meaning: deficient in alertness or activity
example: I found the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there; the patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; her livid face sunk in the pillows: the fire was dying in the grate.

meaning: an embankment built to prevent a river from overflowing
example: Maybe if I ever made it back to Stockton me and Diego could try and start it going at the levee.

meaning: a manner lacking seriousness
example: These elements were acted on by two forces: gravity, the tendency for earth and water to sink, and levity, the tendency for air and fire to rise.

meaning: a segment of the trunk of a tree when stripped of branches
example: The remaining one-third—49 million acres, or an area roughly twice the size of Ohio—is available for logging.

meaning: full of trivial conversation
example: Even the loquacious Mrs. Hubbard was unnaturally quiet.

meaning: transparently clear; easily understandable
example: Propped on the table I found a long, businesslike letter from the summer school and a thin blue letter on leftover Yale stationery, addressed to me in Buddy Willard's lucid hand.

meaning: softly bright or radiant
example: Grey, feathery ashes scurried hither and thither at his breath but no spark shone among them The twins watched anxiously and Piggy sat expressionless behind the luminous wall of his myopia.

meaning: nobility and generosity of spirit
example: Rand held up her hands in a gesture of mock magnanimity.

meaning: someone shirking duty by feigning illness or incapacity
example: If the woman refused, they would report to the office that the woman was a malingerer.

meaning: capable of being shaped or bent
example: Why can’t the Americans see the Communists in their own backyards, in their universities, bending the malleable minds of the young?

meaning: someone who exhibits independence in thought and action
example: He shuffled to the back of the bus, grateful that it wasn’t one of the crowded school buses but a maverick bus that appeared at odd hours.

meaning: given to lying
example: “Especially,” said Charles, “when the batty bandleader is a disingenuous and mendacious charlatan.”

meaning: striking change in appearance or character or circumstances
example: Other scientists are working on the so-called “juvenile hormone,” a powerful substance which prevents metamorphosis of the larval insect until the proper stage of growth has been reached.

meaning: marked by precise accordance with details
example: He had me put in the Mabel Mercer tape and then enlightened me about her meticulous phrasing.

meaning: someone who dislikes people in general
example: Old Abraham, who was not old at all but who had comported himself in the manner of an elderly misanthrope since he first learned to sit up.

meaning: lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
example: Because for a private citizen to become a prince presupposes virtue or Fortune, it appears that either the one or the other of these two things should partially mitigate many of the problems.

meaning: cause to be more favorably inclined
example: Piliso was not mollified by this, and we sensed that something was wrong.

meaning: showing a brooding ill humor
example: Sonia is morose, running a slight fever from her typhoid shot, still expecting, when she enters the living room in the morning, to see a tree trimmed with lights.

meaning: found in the ordinary course of events
example: She imagined him as a child surrounded by too many brightly colored toys, always being encouraged to carry out “projects,” always being told that his mundane ideas were wonderful.

meaning: make ineffective by counterbalancing the effect of
example: Instead, Eliza negated everything I said and suggested I might actually be the problem on the team!

meaning: a participant with no experience with an activity
example: Ben noticed that other Marines were beginning to watch their table as the word of the neophyte drinker spread around the bar.

meaning: stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing
example: So the boy went to the front door, rang the bell, hoping some other less obdurate servant might let him in.

meaning: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
example: No car has ever had such obsequious treatment as did Rocinante as we moved slowly on.

meaning: do away with
example: “Some would contend that this confession would obviate the need for a lengthy trial,” she said in a cold, heartless voice that made Finn miss the real Ms. Morales.

meaning: block passage through
example: But deep in the fields the brownish stalks rise from the earth to more than twice her height, occluding her vision.

meaning: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner
example: A voice is talking to her now, calm and officious.

meaning: burdensome or difficult to endure
example: The insubstantial frost feathers ensured that those last twenty feet remained hard, scary, onerous.

meaning: move or swing from side to side regularly
example: Doctors came running up from every direction with needles, lights, tubes, rubber mallets and oscillating metal tines.

meaning: intended to attract notice and impress others
example: She continued forward, sidestepping open trunks that held plumed garments from every period, curled wigs, and ostentatious hats.

meaning: a perfect embodiment of a concept
example: Founded in 1948, it was, in many ways, meant to be the paragon of suburban life, with mass-produced houses and cookie-cutter yards.

meaning: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
example: “They worry lest we join the partisans . . “As far as I’m concerned, this whole business of deportation is nothing but a big farce.

meaning: relating to the study of diseases
example: I was afraid that maybe he would say we couldn’t keep a dog who went crazy with pathological fear every time there was a crack of thunder.

meaning: an insufficient quantity or number
example: Like Waterman and McCunn, he displayed a staggering paucity of common sense.

meaning: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning
example: The voice that had spoken it was a Scholar’s, precise and pedantic and lazily arrogant, very much a Jordan College voice.

meaning: a strong liking or preference
example: So far, the only blemish on Parker’s record while serving the president is a penchant for tardiness, as Crook knows all too well.

meaning: a state of extreme poverty or destitution
example: He was poor and lived in utter penury.

meaning: lasting an indefinitely long time
example: He saw no reason to change his perennial opinion of her as a sour and fidgety frustration.

meaning: tending to betray
example: He called Nino a ________ traitor and a foolish viper.

meaning: hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough
example: But it came out sounding broad, perfunctory, like the token consolation of a kind stranger.

meaning: allowing fluids or gases to pass or diffuse through
example: He was lonely still, but it was only a mist, a weather front that passed through him when he was alone, a feeling of having turned too permeable.

meaning: spreading or spread throughout
example: The market had priced such companies as if they might go out of business because plenty of information suggested that was a possibility, and because fear was then so ________ that optimism felt almost like a form of irrationality.

meaning: showing little emotion
example: Through the years, old Rena remained phlegmatic, paying no apparent attention to the bedlam which had intruded into her twilight years.

meaning: righteousness by virtue of being religiously devout
example: During this time, owing to his newfound piety, Bobby used no profanity.

meaning: cause to be more favorably inclined
example: Not when invaders were threatening the Empire and the populous had to be placated.

meaning: the property of being physically malleable
example: Explanations of his Effect that focus on changes to the sensory environment are consistent with the growing number of studies that demonstrate the “plasticity” of the human brain.

meaning: a trite or obvious remark
example: Pearl waited for a parental platitude to follow: Life isn’t fair, or Fair doesn’t always mean right.

meaning: extreme excess
example: Now, instead of the plates made of bread, there were covered dishes, scented finger bowls, sumptuous table cloths, a plethora of napkins.

meaning: drop sharply
example: Her face was lit with madness as she shrieked, plummeting toward Mark, who couldn’t believe what he was seeing.

meaning: full of holes
example: Now the magic seemed to have thinned into a tiny trickle dripping through a narrow channel in her porous bones.

meaning: concerned with practical matters
example: While it makes perfect sense to me, this pragmatic view of religion escapes the Reverend utterly.

meaning: a preliminary introduction, as to a statute or constitution
example: He said nothing, and he did not smile, but watched her, wondering to what task this preamble led.

meaning: not secure; beset with difficulties
example: It was a precarious existence, to say the least.

meaning: bring about abruptly
example: “This is enough for me,” he wrote Rush, adding that he knew Adams to be “always an honest man, often a great one, but sometimes incorrect and precipitate in his judgments.”

meaning: something indicating the approach of something or someone
example: That could have been the precursor to an independent African discovery of iron metallurgy.

meaning: going beyond what is appropriate, permitted, or courteous
example: This struck Kamen as presumptuous, for he was the senior member of the team and the one whose work had been the more important.

meaning: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear
example: “Delay, obscure, prevaricate. Oh, no one does that half so well as our brave uncle.”

meaning: immaculately clean and unused
example: At last year’s sales, Mrs. Tonnessen said, the clothes’ ________ condition and vibrant fabrics were impressive; the family had kept them well protected in storage.

meaning: complete and confirmed integrity
example: In both instances his posture of public probity—slavery should be ended and political parties were evil agents that corrupted republican values—was at odds with his personal behavior and political interest.

meaning: making great mental demands
example: It requires an ability to move back and forth between the concrete and the abstract, the immediate example and a scientific theory, and this movement is conceptually and historically problematic.

meaning: recklessly wasteful
example: Glass was expensive, and large sheets of it were prodigal of heat in these fierce latitudes; so to see them here was evidence of wealth and influence far greater than Iofur Raknison’s vulgar palace.

meaning: situated at or extending to great depth
example: It crystallized in the mid- to late 1990s and, when it did, it had as profound an impact on the world as the first two flatteners.

meaning: tending to discourage, especially of prices
example: Meanwhile, Lovelace found the costs of the testing prohibitive, particularly without government funding.

meaning: grow rapidly
example: Most of the work done at Langley was of the “compressed-air” persuasion, research conducted in one of the proliferating number of wind tunnels.

meaning: a natural inclination
example: Limbs, torsos, brains, eyes, faces—even temperaments or propensities that were inherited—had to be created anew each time an embryo unfurled into a human fetus.

meaning: make peace with
example: Especially I felt this when I made any attempt to propitiate him.

meaning: correct behavior
example: Still concerned about propriety, I insisted we keep our blooming relationship out of sight of our colleagues, though it hardly worked.

meaning: command against
example: Soon he was proscribing parts of salutations and signatures and leaving the text untouched.

meaning: strong and sharp to the sense of taste or smell
example: I hugged him tight, his fur smelling like a mix of dogs and vet chemicals, pungent and sterile.

meaning: meeting the proper standards and requirements for a task
example: With senior nurses seconded to casualty-receiving hospitals further out in the hospitals sector, and more cases coming in, the qualified nurses gave orders freely, and the probationers of Briony’s set were given new responsibilities.

meaning: evade the truth of a point by raising irrelevant objections
example: After a spell of indecisive quibbling, Perry said, “I’m for it.”

meaning: being quiet or still or inactive
example: And up from the quiescent, waiting land a faint mist rose, silver as moonlight, and clung about the tree trunks.

meaning: of high moral or intellectual value
example: At a modest high school in the Tidewater city of Portsmouth, not far from John Casteen’s boyhood home, a guidance-office wall filled with college pennants does not include one from rarefied Virginia.

meaning: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
example: Any parent who has ever said to a recalcitrant child, “Okay, I’m going to count to ten and this time I’m really going to punish you,” knows the difference between deterrent and empty threat.

meaning: formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief
example: Milo was sure they would be charitable if he went to them to apologize and recant and promised to fly eighty missions.

meaning: one who lives in solitude
example: His failures had made him a recluse, but people remembered the vulnerable boy he had once been.

meaning: difficult to understand
example: By various recondite processes, he converted the urine first into a noxious paste and then into a translucent warty substance.

meaning: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
example: Then in the Clarkston area of Washington the insects became refractory — they were harder to kill than in the orchards of the Wenatchee and Yakima valleys and elsewhere.

meaning: overthrow by argument, evidence, or proof
example: Parties choose to use scientific evidence to support their positions when it suits them, and ________ the validity of the science when it doesn't.

meaning: assign to a lower position
example: Once labeled a felon, the badge of inferiority remains with you for the rest of your life, relegating you to a permanent second-class status.

meaning: express criticism towards
example: There was her husband’s reproach looking at her from the external things around her which he had provided for her external existence.

meaning: a person without moral scruples
example: “Those old reprobates, they live in my building, you know...”

meaning: refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid
example: And now you have repudiated the character of Lopsang with your “tattle tale” accounts of him.

meaning: cancel officially
example: A number of the newer regulations regarding study and free time were immediately rescinded.

meaning: a decision to do something or to behave in a certain manner
example: “If those captains found a way to leave their monsters behind, they deserve whatever peace they find. They deserve resolution. And the beasts...well, they deserve each other.”

meaning: find a solution or answer
example: And lately some of his creditors had begun exhibiting an extraordinary hardening of resolve.

meaning: reluctant to draw attention to yourself
example: Thus, the girls were no longer always together, and Nancy deeply felt the daytime absence of her friend, the one person with whom she need be neither brave nor reticent.

meaning: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
example: They were books that discussed slavery and plantations and the time before emancipation in a reverent and honorable way, like it had all been a good thing.

meaning: a mentor in spiritual and philosophical topics
example: He had been full of arrogance; he had always been the cleverest, the most eager—always a step ahead of the others, always the learned and intellectual one, always the priest or the ________.

meaning: promoting health
example: A fine mist of pulverized concrete seems to cover everything, and the once salubrious climate is overwhelmed by smog.

meaning: official permission or approval
example: The Eminent Persons Group had come with many questions involving the issues of violence, negotiations, and international sanctions.

meaning: fill to satisfaction
example: As soon as this happened, they cheerfully abandoned the gruelling, dangerous, and often spartan life of hunter-gatherers, settling down to enjoy the pleasant, satiated life of farmers.

meaning: infuse or fill completely
example: When freshly cut fruits or vegetables are spread out they immediately begin to evaporate moisture into the air, and if in a closed box will very soon ________ the air with moisture.

meaning: a particular taste or smell, especially an appealing one
example: After a brisk tour of Salamanca’s historic center and its lovely Plaza Mayor, we defied the custom of ________ one’s meals and ordered a few appetizers to go.

meaning: generate and separate from cells or bodily fluids
example: “Take with water and within seconds your fingers will secrete a transdermal poison. Anyone you touch for the next hour will be instantly and painlessly gleaned.”

meaning: a broken piece of a brittle artifact
example: When I open the box, I see broken shards of my Christmas ornament, along with burned scraps of what must be my father’s painting.

meaning: someone who habitually doubts accepted beliefs
example: I’m not sure it is going to convince ________ that science and faith are so easily compatible.

meaning: inducing sleep
example: He was a man of high professional standards, a careful and deliberate, exacting judge who held himself to the letter of the law, however soporifically.

meaning: plausible but false
example: As such, it was of course vulnerable to the same variety of glibly undaunted and usually specious evaluations that any legitimate art object is.

meaning: a broad range of related objects, values, or qualities
example: I walked over, gave him a pound, and felt that heat of the spectrum, the warmth of The Mecca.

meaning: recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances
example: The distant boom of artillery switched from its sporadic night rhythm to the purposeful daylight pounding.

meaning: a symbol of disgrace or infamy
example: I argue that the shame and stigma of the “prison label” are, in many respects, more damaging to the African American community than the shame and stigma associated with Jim Crow.

meaning: supply sparingly and with restricted quantities
example: After stints in North Carolina, New York, Florida, Virginia, California, and a handful of other states, he returned home to southern Maryland and started work at a job that would change his life.

meaning: make an express demand or provision in an agreement
example: Although this attitude wasn’t uncommon at the time, NIH guidelines stipulated that all human subject research funded by NIH—as McKusick’s was —required both informed consent and approval from a Hopkins review board.

meaning: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
example: After its uncertain launch, its stolid reliability had become almost boring; the Crocker Lab seemed more like an industrial factory every day, so why not push past the boundaries of the predictable once again?

meaning: walk in a proud, confident way
example: In the distance I hear Mrs. Walton’s signature click-clack strut as she makes her way toward the counter.

meaning: a writ issued to compel the attendance of a witness
example: The phone company had to make sure the subpoena was in order.

meaning: wear off or die down
example: He looked at me with consternation as my coughing subsided to spluttering and then, finally, to painful wrenching hiccups.

meaning: establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts
example: White hadn’t been able to substantiate Kenny’s allegations, but he wasn’t sure what to make of Comstock, either.

meaning: take the place or move into the position of
example: That is, they still used stone tools similar to those superseded in Europe by metal tools thousands of years ago, and they dwelt in villages not organized under any centralized political authority.

meaning: the cognitive process of conjecturing
example: She knew well there had to be such forms of bureaucratic supposition.

meaning: implied by or inferred from actions or statements
example: Before I had been made to go to church, I had given God’s existence a sort of tacit assent, but after having seen His creatures serve Him at first hand, I had had my doubts.

meaning: of superficial relevance if any
example: Something visceral and less tangential than, say, statistics, laws, police enforcement, or television commercials: The issue had to be made personal.

meaning: lacking substance or significance
example: Maybeth smiled, a tenuous little smile, and turned back to the window.

meaning: a speech of violent denunciation
example: Shoving a plastic cup under my nose, the mother launched her tirade.

meaning: a state of motor and mental inactivity
example: He was in one of his reptilian torpors again.

meaning: marked by repeated turns and bends
example: Laila remembered Tariq’s hands, soft but strong, the tortuous, full veins on the backs of them, which she had always found so appealingly masculine.

meaning: easily managed
example: "Joff will be no more tractable for you than for me."

meaning: the violation of a law or a duty or moral principle
example: By this stage, however, Owen’s transgressions were beginning to catch up with him.

meaning: stubborn and defiant aggressiveness
example: Instead of returning the salute, Bull stopped the car completely and stared with visible truculence at the guard who held his salute as rigidly as some umpires who call strikes on batters with exaggerated formality.

meaning: be undecided about something
example: My love for him vacillated from one entry to another.

meaning: regard with feelings of respect and reverence
example: This was always followed by Collins’s Ode on the Passions, wherein I particularly venerated Mr. Wopsle as Revenge throwing his blood-stained sword in thunder down, and taking the War-denouncing trumpet with a withering look.

meaning: habitually speaking the truth
example: “These are the creatures,” he wrote, “that prove fairy tales to be more veracious than ancient history.”

meaning: using or containing too many words
example: His account is simple and straightforward; Ovid’s extremely verbose—for instance, he takes a hundred lines to kill the sea serpent.

meaning: capable of life or normal growth and development
example: Once I remove them from their power docks, they will only stay viable for thirty minutes.

meaning: having a relatively high resistance to flow
example: In a steamer it takes two or three days to cross the North Sea—so many hours of slobbering through the viscous water.

meaning: marked by harshly abusive criticism
example: The story he told was drunken and garbled, out of sequence and full of vituperative, self-righteous digressions; but I had no problem understanding it.

meaning: liable to lead to sudden change or violence
example: And the nation’s economic depression was growing steadily worse, its labor situation more volatile.

meaning: marked by keen caution and watchful prudence
example: Barry hovered across the room, looking as wary as she felt.

meaning: a confused multitude of things
example: I can’t start to describe for you my welter of emotions.

meaning: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
example: Gabe tried to remember its name; he could picture Nathaniel's sister laughing when she had told it to him, but the whimsical name eluded him.

meaning: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
example: Religious zealots and religious dissenters were making noise while members of the Church of England and Unitarians like the Darwins also quietly questioned their faith.
